stories.title: Founder of sneaker empire is betting that trading cards are the next NFTs

stories.text: I'm a big fan of shows like Bob's Burgers, the early years of the Simpsons, etc. and I've been rewatching Bob's Burgers in preparation of seeing the movie and noticed that there are a ton of musical numbers. It seems something that happens genre-wide but I don't see it in other tv categories. Any idea why it's so prevalent in animated shows like those?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why do animated shows tend to have so many musical numbers?
Musk's warning could be auto industry's 'canary in the coal mine' moment
Top Meta Exec Sandberg Quit Amid Probe into Wedding Expenses

stories.text:
Greetings. Apologies for the title, but it's length is rather limited.

I'm asking, because I've seen the article about google's simd based quicksort, and because I've actually thought about this recently.

I've neglected to pursue this problem, because I was thinking that there's no point to it anymore. I was thinking that everything solved to best efficiency already anyway, so why bother?

Am I wrong? Is there still room for improving efficiency/performance of at least some functions/algorithms out there?

If so ... what should I tackle? To make this easier, just assume I can improve literally anything, as long as there's still room for it, and throw the challenges/problems at me! :D

Thank you!
stories.title: Ask HN: Optimizing established functions/code, like QS. There's still a point?
